title: NIPS_2016_80_abs

sentences.text: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor -LRB- NN -RRB- search have in large part focused on 2 distance .
Here we develop an approach for 1 distance that begins with an explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding of the points into 2 2 .
We show how this can efficiently be combined with random-projection based methods for 2 NN search , such as locality-sensitive hashing -LRB- LSH -RRB- or random projection trees .
We rigorously establish the correctness of the methodology and show by experimentation using LSH that it is competitive in practice with available alternatives .

Entity-2_nn_search.label: 2 NN search
Entity-2_nn_search.description: 2 NN search refers to a method for finding the two nearest neighbors of a given point in a dataset, often utilized in various search algorithms and techniques such as locality-sensitive hashing.

Entity-an_approach_for_1_distance.label: an approach for 1 distance
Entity-an_approach_for_1_distance.description: An approach for 1 distance refers to a method for nearest neighbor search that utilizes a distance-preserving embedding of data points into a two-dimensional space, enabling efficient integration with random-projection techniques for improved search performance.

Entity-fast_algorithm_for_nearest_neighb.label: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor
Entity-fast_algorithm_for_nearest_neighb.description: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor refer to efficient computational methods designed to quickly identify the closest points in a dataset based on distance metrics, particularly focusing on optimizing search techniques for various distance measures.

Entity-random_projection_tree.label: random projection trees
Entity-random_projection_tree.description: Random projection trees are a type of data structure and algorithm used for dimensionality reduction and efficient nearest neighbor search by leveraging random projections.

Entity-lsh.label: LSH
Entity-lsh.description: LSH refers to Locality-Sensitive Hashing, a method used in computer science for performing probabilistic dimension reduction of high-dimensional data, enabling efficient approximate nearest neighbor searches.

Entity-experimentation_using_lsh.label: experimentation using LSH
Entity-experimentation_using_lsh.description: Experimentation using LSH refers to the practical evaluation and comparison of a proposed nearest neighbor search methodology that incorporates locality-sensitive hashing to assess its performance against existing alternatives.

Entity-nn.label: NN
Entity-nn.description: NN refers to 'nearest neighbor', a method used in search algorithms to find the closest points in a dataset based on distance metrics.

Entity-explicit_and_exactly_distance-pre.label: explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding
Entity-explicit_and_exactly_distance-pre.description: The 'explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding' refers to a mathematical technique used to transform points into a higher-dimensional space while preserving the distances between them exactly, facilitating efficient nearest neighbor search in 2-dimensional space.

Entity-nearest_neighbor.label: nearest neighbor
Entity-nearest_neighbor.description: Nearest neighbor refers to a type of algorithm used in machine learning and data analysis that identifies the closest data points in a dataset based on a defined distance metric.

Entity-correctness_of_the_methodology.label: correctness of the methodology
Entity-correctness_of_the_methodology.description: The 'correctness of the methodology' refers to the validation and reliability of the proposed approach for nearest neighbor search that utilizes a distance-preserving embedding and random-projection techniques.

Entity-locality-sensitive_hashing.label: locality-sensitive hashing
Entity-locality-sensitive_hashing.description: Locality-sensitive hashing is a technique used in computer science for performing probabilistic dimension reduction of high-dimensional data, enabling efficient similarity searches by hashing similar input items into the same buckets with high probability.

Entity-distance-preserving_embedding.label: distance-preserving embedding
Entity-distance-preserving_embedding.description: A distance-preserving embedding is a mathematical technique that transforms data points from one metric space to another while maintaining the exact distances between the points, facilitating efficient nearest neighbor search.

Entity-2_distance.label: 2 distance
Entity-2_distance.description: The term '2 distance' refers to a distance metric commonly used in nearest neighbor search algorithms, specifically the Euclidean distance, which measures the straight-line distance between two points in a multi-dimensional space.

Entity-embedding.label: embedding
Entity-embedding.description: The term 'embedding' refers to a mathematical transformation that explicitly and exactly preserves distances when mapping points from one space to another, specifically in the context of nearest neighbor search.

Entity-2_2.description: The mention '2 2' refers to a two-dimensional mathematical space used for embedding points in the context of nearest neighbor search algorithms.

Entity-random-projection_based_method.label: random-projection based methods
Entity-random-projection_based_method.description: Random-projection based methods are data processing techniques that utilize random projections to reduce the dimensionality of data while preserving its structure, often used in machine learning and data analysis tasks.

Entity-distance.label: distance
Entity-distance.description: In the context of nearest neighbor search, 'distance' refers to a mathematical concept that quantifies the separation between points in a metric space, specifically focusing on the 2-distance metric in this paper.

Entity-1_distance.label: 1 distance
Entity-1_distance.description: 1 distance refers to a metric used in nearest neighbor search that is based on the Manhattan distance, which is characterized by the sum of the absolute differences of their coordinates.

Entity-available_alternative.label: available alternatives
Entity-available_alternative.description: The term 'available alternatives' refers to other existing methods or algorithms for nearest neighbor search that can be compared against the proposed approach in the paper.

Entity-point.label: points
Entity-point.description: The term 'points' refers to mathematical objects that represent data in a multi-dimensional space, which are being embedded for the purpose of nearest neighbor search in the context of distance metrics.

Entity-algorithm.label: algorithms
Entity-algorithm.description: Algorithms are systematic procedures or formulas used for solving problems or performing tasks, particularly in computational contexts.

Entity-methodology.label: methodology
Entity-methodology.description: Methodology refers to a systematic procedure or approach used in research to collect, analyze, and interpret data.

Entity-experimentation.label: experimentation
Entity-experimentation.description: Experimentation is a systematic process used in research to test hypotheses and validate methodologies through controlled trials and empirical observation.

summary: Fast algorithms for nearest neighbor -LRB- NN -RRB- search have in large part focused on 2 distance . Here we develop an approach for 1 distance that begins with an explicit and exactly distance-preserving embedding of the points into 2 2 . We show how this can efficiently be combined with random-projection based methods for 2 NN search , such as locality-sensitive hashing -LRB- LSH -RRB- or random projection trees . We rigorously establish the correctness of the methodology and show by experimentation using LSH that it is competitive in practice with available alternatives .

Predicate-focused_on.label: focused on
Predicate-focused_on.description: The predicate 'focused on' indicates a relationship where the subject is concentrating its attention, resources, or efforts towards the object. It implies a prioritization or emphasis on the object in relation to the subject, suggesting that the subject is particularly concerned with, or dedicated to, the aspects or characteristics represented by the object.

This relationship suggests that the subject is actively engaged in research, innovation, or application that leads to the establishment or refinement of the object, which often represents a concept, method, or technology.

Predicate-embeds.label: embeds

This relationship suggests that the object is represented within the subject in a way that maintains specific structural or relational attributes.

Predicate-combined_with.label: combined with
Predicate-combined_with.description: The predicate 'combined with' indicates a relationship where the subject and object are brought together or integrated to form a unified entity or to enhance functionality. It suggests that the two elements work in conjunction, often resulting in improved performance, capabilities, or outcomes when used together.

Predicate-are_used_for.label: are used for
Predicate-are_used_for.description: The predicate 'are used for' indicates the purpose or application of the subject in relation to the object. It connects the subject, which represents a method, technique, or tool, to the object, which signifies a specific task, function, or area of application where the subject is employed. This relationship highlights how the subject contributes to achieving the objectives associated with the object.

Predicate-is_used_in.label: is used in
Predicate-is_used_in.description: The predicate 'is used in' establishes a relationship where the subject is a tool, method, or concept that plays a role or serves a purpose within the context of the object. It indicates that the subject contributes to, facilitates, or is applied in the activities or processes described by the object.

Predicate-establishes.label: establishes
Predicate-establishes.description: The predicate 'establishes' denotes a relationship in which the subject is responsible for creating, confirming, or validating the existence or truth of the object. It implies a process of foundation or proof, where the subject provides evidence or reasoning that supports the object, thereby affirming its validity or significance.

Predicate-is_competitive_in_practice_wit.label: is competitive in practice with
Predicate-is_competitive_in_practice_wit.description: The predicate 'is competitive in practice with' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject performs comparably or favorably in practical applications when compared to the object. This suggests that the subject is capable of achieving similar or better outcomes, efficiency, or effectiveness in real-world scenarios relative to the object, which represents other methods, approaches, or solutions in the same domain.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: The predicate 'shows' indicates a relationship where the subject provides evidence, demonstration, or illustration of the truth, validity, or existence of the object. It implies that the subject serves as a means to reveal or make apparent the qualities or characteristics of the object.

Predicate-is_competitive_with.label: is competitive with
Predicate-is_competitive_with.description: The predicate 'is competitive with' indicates a relationship where the subject is positioned in a context of rivalry or comparison with the object, suggesting that both entities vie for the same advantages, resources, or recognition within a particular domain or field. This relationship implies that the subject and object are alternatives to each other, and their effectiveness, quality, or desirability can be evaluated against one another.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or concept that falls under the wider category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a broader scope or definition that includes the subject as a subset.
